Is this genuinely how it works in America? What age exactly is high school? Is there no mechanism for telling your parents or punishing you if you don't turn up to classes?

Is this genuinely how it works in America? What age exactly is high school? Is there no mechanism for telling your parents or punishing you if you don't turn up to classes?

 
 Basically, there's a school. The bell rings a few minutes in advance to tell everyone to go to class. If you show up late to class, you get a tardy, and if you don't show up at all you get an unexcused absence. 3 tardies = 1 unexcused absence. 5 unexcused absences = LC, loss of credit. You have to retake the course again and it shows up as an F on a report card.
 
 As to notifying parents, I don't think they do at all until the kid actually has an LC. I got a note last year saying I had LC'd a class, apparently my baseball coach forgot to send the note in excusing me from class, but I got no warning at all before that. But I got that straightened out :)
 
 Now if you bring in a note as an excuse for missing they call the parent that day to verify. So basically it's up to you to get to class. If you don't they require a note (which they will call parents to verify, so they care about recording it as excused when it's not, but not about kids failing) to get it excused.
 
 Now obviously a teacher can call a parent for whatever reason. I'm not sure if that happens but the one class I'm in where people skip frequently (PE, at the beginning of the day, many kids just show up late) the teacher doesn't care. He marks them absent and the rest is up to the school. Now there's no way for the teacher to know if it's excused or not. So basically it's up to the kid to get to class, which isn't all that hard of a thing to do anyway.
 
 
 That's how it works at our school, I don't know if it's the same throughout the country, but high school is supposed to teach responsibility. The ages are usually around 14-18.
